claim: Most school children in New York would be wearing jackets on groundhog day.

supporting.text: Groundhog Day occurs on February 2nd, which is typically one of the coldest months in New York, necessitating jackets for warmth.

attacks.text: Groundhog Day occurs on February 2nd, which is typically one of the coldest months in New York, necessitating jackets for warmth.
New York City has experienced unusually warm temperatures in recent Februarys due to climate change, reducing the need for jackets.
Even during warmer winters, mornings and evenings on February 2nd can still be cold enough to require jackets for children.
Many schools in New York have indoor heating systems that make jackets unnecessary while inside the building.
Children typically spend time outdoors during recess or commuting to school, where jackets are still necessary despite indoor heating.

supporting.text: New York experiences average temperatures well below freezing in February, making jackets essential for children outdoors.

attacks.text: New York experiences average temperatures well below freezing in February, making jackets essential for children outdoors.
Many schools in New York have indoor heating, and children may not wear jackets inside, reducing the overall necessity.
Even indoors, children often wear jackets when moving between buildings or during outdoor activities like recess.
Some children may have high cold tolerance or come from cultures where jackets are less commonly worn in cold weather.
Schools typically enforce dress codes that include jackets in cold weather for safety and health reasons.

supporting.text: Schools in New York often require or strongly recommend jackets for children during winter months for health and safety reasons.

attacks.text: Schools in New York often require or strongly recommend jackets for children during winter months for health and safety reasons.
Groundhog Day is not always in the coldest part of winter, and some years may have unseasonably warm weather, reducing the need for jackets.
Even on warmer Groundhog Days, schools may still enforce jacket policies due to liability concerns and unpredictable weather changes.
Many children may choose not to wear jackets even if recommended, especially older students who prioritize fashion or comfort over school policies.
Schools often monitor and enforce dress codes strictly, especially for younger children, ensuring compliance with jacket recommendations.

supporting.text: Parents typically dress their children in jackets during cold weather to prevent illness, and February in New York is consistently cold.

attacks.text: Parents typically dress their children in jackets during cold weather to prevent illness, and February in New York is consistently cold.
Not all parents strictly enforce jacket-wearing, especially if children resist or if the school has indoor heating.
Schools often require outdoor recess, and teachers or staff may enforce jacket policies during cold weather.
Groundhog Day (Feb 2) sometimes has unseasonably warm weather in New York, reducing jacket usage.
Historical weather data shows February in New York is overwhelmingly cold, making warm Groundhog Days rare exceptions.

supporting.text: Historical weather data for New York shows that February temperatures frequently necessitate winter clothing, including jackets.

attacks.text: Historical weather data for New York shows that February temperatures frequently necessitate winter clothing, including jackets.
Recent climate trends indicate warmer February temperatures in New York, reducing the necessity for jackets.
Despite warmer trends, groundhog day in February still often falls within the coldest period of winter in New York.
Many school children in New York attend schools with strict indoor heating policies, reducing the need for jackets even on cold days.
Children typically spend time outdoors during recess or commuting, where jackets are necessary despite indoor heating.
